Award.AwardTitle: Tri-trophic consequences of herbivore diet breadth and plant resistance
Award.AbstractNarration:
A fundamental goal of ecology and evolutionary biology is to elucidate the factors that determine what proportion of plant biomass is consumed by herbivores. Ecologists have long recognized that predators play a role by suppressing herbivore populations. At the same time, work by evolutionary biologists has shown that the vulnerability of an herbivore species to predators is determined by both plant nutritional quality and the diversity of plant species included in that herbivore's diet. The work funded here seeks to integrate these separate but complementary areas of research. The overarching hypothesis to be tested is that plant nutritional quality and herbivore diet breadth together determine an herbivore's vulnerability to predators. In so doing, plant quality and herbivore diet breadth are predicted to determine the importance of predators in plant protection, as well whether predators act as source of natural selection that influences the evolution of plant nutritional quality. The proposed work tests this hypothesis using an experimental garden of native shrubs and their associated insect community. Genetic lines of plants that vary in nutritional quality will be grown in experimental treatments with herbivores alone and with herbivores and predators together. These plants will be fed upon by one of two species of herbivore: an aphid that feeds only on one plant species or an aphid that feeds on a wide diversity of plants. This experiment will thus measure the effects of predators on herbivores and plants, and how such effects are determined by herbivore diet breadth and plant quality.

The primary broader impact is an initiative to establish a public garden of native shrubs in the University of California-Irvine Arboretum, one of two botanical gardens featuring the native flora of California in Orange County (population > 3 million). This display will provide the public with a hands-on demonstration of the variation in plant traits that determine its nutritional quality for herbivores, as well as information on the natural history of the associated insect community. The garden will also serve as a key resource for independent research and teaching opportunities for undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ecological research has long sought to reveal the factors that mediate the cascading effects of predators directly on herbivores and indirectly on plants. At the same time, evolutionary research on the interactions between plants and herbivorous insects has investigated the factors driving the evolution of herbivore diet breadth (the number of plant species eaten) and host plant defenses against herbivores (e.g. spines, poisons). Our research has made significant steps towards integrating these separate, but complementary areas of research.

Studying two separate model food webs, our primary finding is that host plant defense and herbivore diet breadth interactively mediate the strength of predator's cascading effects directly on herbivores and indirectly on plants.

Our studies show that herbivores that specialize on one or a few host plant species are less susceptible to plant defenses, likely due to increased physiological efficiency, and also are less vulnerable to predators, likely due to their ability to tailor their appearance to achieve superior camouflage. This finding explains the evolutionary advantages to herbivores' specializing on one or a few host plant species. These historic evolutionary processes in turn have contemporary ecological consequences; predators have relatively weak effects on herbivores and plants when acting on dietary specialist herbivores, and plant defenses do not mediate these predator effects.  In contrast, herbivores that have a broad diet breadth are more susceptible to plant defenses, and are also more vulnerable to the effects of predators. As a result, predators have relatively strong effects on herbivores and plants when acting on dietary generalist herbivores, and plant defenses mediate these effects by rendering herbivores more susceptible.  

Our findings thus serve to unite two previously separate fields of ecological study (on how predators influence the abundance of herbivores and plants) and evolutionary study (of plant defense and herbivore diet breadth), and we have disseminated these findings through 10 peer­reviewed publications, 12 presentations at national scientific meetings and 11 invited research seminars.

There are also significant broader impacts of our work. Our findings have implications not only for understanding the ecological and evolutionary dynamics of natural ecosystems, but also for control of biological control of herbivores by predators in agricultural systems. As a member of UC­Irvine’s Center for Environmental Biology, the PI has worked closely with local land managers to disseminate this work. While the scope of research funded by this grant was not directly related to land management, there is nevertheless significant potential for these findings to inform management and restoration practices.

 Participation in this project has provided significant training opportunities in experimental design and execution, statistical analysis, scientific writing and public speaking. In total, this project has provided such opportunities to two postdoctoral scholars, three graduate students, and six undergraduate students. In addition, this project has provided educational opportunities annually to undergraduate students from two field courses in ecology and entomology. These personnel have thus acquired skills that can benefit them many careers, including work in both basic and applied ecology.
